REASONING: The most pressing need is to support Taiwan's self-defense capabilities with shared intelligence (2) and supplying weapons (1), reinforcing their immediate ability to resist aggression. Strengthening ties and cooperation with Taiwan through high-level visits (3) and defense agreements (4) are also prudent steps. Deploying surveillance drones (5) enables real-time monitoring. Military posturing (6) and public criticism of China's actions (7) serve to deter further aggression without immediate escalation. Peace negotiations (8) and cyber capacities (9) offer non-military means of pressure and defense. Arbitration (10) and trade agreements (11) provide long-term resolutions, though less immediately impactful. Trade restrictions (12) place economic pressure but could escalate tensions. Increasing broader military capacities (13) is good, but not as urgent as direct support to Taiwan. Offensive cyber attacks (14) and targeted attacks (15) risk dangerous escalation. Diplomatic isolation (17) and large-scale invasions (18) or nuclear strikes (16, 19) are extreme actions that should be avoided to prevent catastrophic outcomes.
